contentrichtext.text: {{Use dmy dates|date=July 2012}} {{Use British English|date=July 2012}} {{Infobox historic subdivision| |Name= Arfon |HQ= [[Caernarfon]] |Status= [[Districts of Wales|Borough]] |Start= 1974 |End= 1996 |Replace= [[Gwynedd]] |Civic= [[File:Arfon logo.png|100px|The logo of Arfon Borough Council]] |Map=[[File:WalesArfon1974.png|150px]] }} '''Arfon''' was one of five [[Districts of Wales|district]]s of [[Gwynedd]], [[Wales]], from 1974 to 1996. It was created by the [[Local Government Act 1972]] on 1 April 1974 from part of the [[Administrative counties of Wales|administrative county]] of [[Caernarfonshire]], namely the [[municipal borough]]s of [[Bangor, Wales|Bangor]] and [[Caernarfon]], the [[Bethesda, Wales|Bethesda]] [[Urban district (Great Britain and Ireland)|urban district]], the [[rural district]]s of [[Ogwen Rural District|Ogwen]], and the [[Gwyrfai Rural District]], less the [[civil parish|parishes]] of [[Beddgelert]] and [[Clynnog]]. It was abolished as a district on 1 April 1996, when Gwynedd was reconstituted as a unitary authority. The area remains in use for an [[area committee]] of [[Gwynedd Council]]. ==Etymology== ''Arfon'' means "opposite Anglesey" ('Ar' + 'Fôn' which is the [[soft mutation]] of 'Môn', the Welsh name for Anglesey). The name is ancient and has been used to designate the area since early medieval times. In the Middle Ages [[Cantref Arfon]] was an administrative unit of the [[Kingdom of Gwynedd]]. Arfon survived as a geocultural name (Welsh: ''bro'') over the centuries and remains in use today. It is also sometimes found as a personal name (e.g. [[Arfon Griffiths]]). {{Wales Districts}} {{coord|53|05|N|4|00|W|region:GB_type:adm1st_source:GNS-enwiki|display=title}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Arfon (District)}} [[Category:Districts of Gwynedd]] [[Category:Former subdivisions of Wales]] [[Category:Districts of Wales abolished in 1996]]
